Hi everyone. I am hoping someone can help me with an issue I am having. I have a third party who is looking to share contact data through an API into a HubSpot form I have created. They have mapped the properties and are posting the data to a URL which holds only the form. When submitting they are getting a 'Request Forbidden' response. Any ideas on how to fix this/manage it in a simpler way (I don't currently have CMS hub and am not sure if there are any IP restrictions)? Further to this is there a way to set up a key authorisation? Thanks!
if you look at the scopes, they are maybe related to the api calls and how they are segmented, so if your app is going to need contacts, then you probably want contacts read and write

there is a sales chrome extension that bcc a HubSpot email address and causes all those emails to be imported to the contact record.

If you are talking about some other type of emailing, let me know
Is this what you are looking for? <https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/api/crm/extensions/custom-cards>
They should use the forms api to submit. You’ll need to provide them with the form guid and the portal id

Ok, let me give a bit more context

The app triggers when the deal is moved to the dealstage "legal" or more precisely when the property "deal timestamp: became legal" has a new date.

So when de first run is not successful due to missing info, the sales rep get an email to fill out the missing info. once they have supplied this info they will rerun the integration to create a contract with the full info.
so you want to retrigger the send of data to the output
Exactly! Sorry for confusion of words and explanation

its cool! I am dense anyways, lemme ask a few more questions…

Are you able to change the trigger on the webhook send? If so create another one that triggers the send of data when you have it all. That provides coverrage to remind someone internally to fill it out, but still sends on everything being updated.

As far as getting the button added, you might want to look at how to add an action hook

```{
  "type": "ACTION_HOOK",
  "httpMethod": "POST",
  "uri": "<https://example.com/action-hook>",
  "label": "Example action",
  "associatedObjectProperties": [
    "some_crm_property"
  ]
}```

I have not fully developed a crm extension like you are doing, so I’m probably not the best person to get you further. I have watched this video from developer day a few times: <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KP6H4QiBbFs>

sean goes over the pieces pretty well here — might help you quite a bit.

As far as looking at the app crm card logs, I’m guessing this can be done in local development if you are using the CLI, however I could be very wrong about that

Hi Everyone!
I am seeking a deeper understanding of API data from HS & 3rd party tools.
It has become my mission to gain insight regarding what parameters/metrics/sources HubSpot APIs are pushing to third party tools (especially PPC tools).  The goal is to identify if I was to switch one of our clients to enterprise, would we be able to more accurately unify our data across platforms using HubSpot as the source of truth.  The data would encompass website traffic, ppc, email, sales pipeline, and social data at minimum.  Currently the client has one brand domain and two active websites which is causing issues getting HubSpot data accurately represented in Google Data Studio among other softwares as well.  Below is the two questions I am seeking answers for.

1. If we had two brand domains, does the api support brand data segmentation to google data studio and other PPC channels?
2. What are the sources (lifecycle stages, contact properties, behavior events, etc) HubSpot APIs are using to delineate information (such as date) being sent to third party software?

Hi, I’m migrating from the HubSpot API key to a private app. Would someone double check if these scopes allow the following API endpoints?

The integrations used are:
<http://api.hubapi.com/forms/v2/fields|api.hubapi.com/forms/v2/fields> and  <http://api.hubapi.com/contacts/v1/contact/email|api.hubapi.com/contacts/v1/contact/email>

The scopes enabled in the private app are:
• forms
• crm.objects.contacts.read
• crm.objects.contacts.write
your edits :thumbsup:
and assuming you will be sending data to the contacts endpoint.  if not, read is probably all you need

<@UD53A9UUR> Thanks! regarding that,
if I were updating or reading company properties, I’d use:
• crm.objects.companies.write
• crm.objects.companies.read
All seems straightforward; just making sure i’m not missing anything.
yup!
worse case, test in postman.  the nice thing about private apps is that you do not need to reauth after updating scopes
appreciate it
